Peter Sol Reinach

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/9818580675700596
  • Última atualização do currículo em 25/06/2014

PETER SOL REINACH graduated from New York University and obtained a Ph.D. degree in Biophysics in 1972. He is Distinguished Teaching Professor of Biological Science of State University of New York-SUNY and was Director of the Cell Physiology Laboratory until 2013,July. He has had extensive teaching experience at the undergraduate and professional school level. Initially, he focused on studying epithelial ion transport mechanisms as a post doctoral fellow at Mount Sinai School of Medicine in the Department of Ophthalmology and corneal epithelial bioenergetics. His sustaining interest throughout his career is directed towards characterizing cell signaling pathways mediating receptor control of corneal epithelial renewal. At SUNY he focused on identifying novel drug targets to suppress injury-induced scarring, dysregulated corneal inflammation and hasten wound healing. His efforts were supported for over 30 years by NEI and Department of Defense grants. In addition, he received support from several drug companies and private foundations. In the last 10 years, he trained 8 Ph.D. graduate students. He also provided scientific advisory support for several international drug companies. He has 137 publications in peer reviewed high specialty journals and nearly 4,000 citations. Furthermore, he is an invited author of book chapters and review articles as well as being a reviewer for The Center for Scientifc Review at NIH, Burroughs Welcome Trust, Israel Scientific Review and Fight for Sight as well as for numerous high impact scientific journals. In addition to being a Chancellor Award recipient, he has worked as a visiting professor at Tokyo University, Jiaotong University, Kyoto University, Physiologisches Institut, Universtat Munchen and University of Sao Paulo in the Department of Physics in Sao Carlos followed by relocation to the Department of Ophthalmology and Pharmacology at University of Sao Paulo in Ribeirao Preto until February 2014. At the latter appointment, his efforts were directed towards studying mechanisms underlying inflammatory and neuropathic responses in animal models of injury and disease. Currently, he is a professor in the Departament of Ophthalmology and Optometry at Wenzhou Medical University in Wenzhou, China, where his focus involves studying epigenetic control of corneal epithelial renewal following injury. In addition, he has a part time appointment at SUNY, State College of Optometry, teaching Ocular Immunology as well as providing advisory support to researchers studying dry eye disease. (Texto informado pelo autor)
